title: Stored XSS in Slack (weird, trial and error)

profile.name: Slack
profile.about: All your team communication in one place, instantly searchable, and available wherever you go.

vulnerability_information: Hi slack. I found a weird, trial and error Stored XSS in Slack... I hope you can get clear of this and get it too.. and I hope you can find the XSS too. Anyway here it is (according to what I did): 1. Go to your Slack or create a new Slack team. 2. In slackbot.. enter this payload:

activities.message:
Thank you for your report.

In your video, it seems that you place your payload in a number of different locations, but none of these causes the JavaScript to execute.  However, at the end of your video, you switch teams, which causes a previously defined payload to execute.  Can you be more specific about where you think you entered the payload on *that* team to cause the payload to execute?  We need to be able to reproduce the behavior to further evaluate your report, so it would help us if you could narrow down where you entered your payload.  It is also helpful when testing for XSS in multiple fields, to use different payloads in different areas.  That way, if the payload executes, you can tell which one worked.

Thanks, and good luck with your future bug hunting.

hey! looks like I found the culprit or what is the cause... it is located in yourdomain.slack.com/files .. the SVG file (payload) is being rendered there,but reflected in the main page. Although this is considered as Stored XSS. I will provide screenshot and in the screenshot you will see (I inspect elemnted it). Hope you understand!

Also, looking into the source code of yourdomain.slack.com/files (view page source), and look for the payload, it is inside <script> tags, indicating the XSS... 

e.g.
<script>
          blabal.. payload
</script>

just look at the source code of the site... I hope you can see and reproduce it too.
Thanks!

Hi. Sorry for those long reports I have submitted before. I have now a video indicating the summarized details on how to reproduce the Stored XSS.
I hope its all clear now. Thanks!

Video link: https://youtu.be/kBQ4BNvC5rY
Hi. I would like to add a screenshot. This time I used document.cookie, indicating that cookies are involved too. Thanks
Thanks for sending this our way and excellent find! We have created an internal bug to track this and will keep you posted.
Glad you were able to reproduce it.. thanks!
Hi. tried to reproduce the issue again... looks like its fixed?..

Hey harry_mg,

We've resolved this issue, and are going to issue you a bounty!  Thanks for your report, and happy bug hunting in the future!  

Cheers,
Slack
